div.p:
on receiving your note I
wrote to Mr Cuker mentioning the 2 grievances
viz the nonarrival of the XmasChristmas box & the mysterious
history of the £30 bill. I now enclose his answer &
hope everything is right : or if not that you will
be so good as to write to me again. For of all
-ities I know none less to be countenanced than
that of giving things to Booksellers who either can afford
to pay for them, or ought not to think of publishing
at all. Your charming Garryowen is I am
afraid the only article in the book that is
worth anything - and surely surely it is
worth much more than £30. However when
a sum appears too small there are two ways
of reviewing the matter first it cut
Francs & 2dly considering that after all it

PS.
Sir Walter &
Anne Scott
are now in
Edinr & all
in high health
& spirits. Pray
have the kindness
to give my best
respects to the
hospitable Lady
of the house. I
hope Mrs Butler
is well.

will buy such & such good things for example £30
will produce 6 dozen of excellent Champagne
of 10 dozen- of old Post - how much Whiskey
you best can calculate.

My wife sends all her love. She is well & strong &
poor Johnny has for the present all the appearance of
having made an almost miraculous recovery.
He is able to walk run & play & read all
the books that Grandpapa & Miss Edgeworth have
been pleased to write for the benefit of the young
idea - not forgetting Garryowen which I have seen
him poring over these last ten days ever & anon. The
Second series of Sir Walter's Stories from Scots history
came to hand last night & I have devoured
half of them already. They are all full of
his odd picturesque highland & border anecdotes
& will charm you I think. His novel called the
Maiden of Something - a Swiss & Burgundian story -

is to be ready by XmasChristmas - Are we to hope for Taking
for Granted or Something of that sort of stuff &
moment from Edgeworthstown this season also? I
hope so for the "fashionable Novels have quite
sickened everybody - But I dont include Mr Ward
who has pleased everyone else as well as the
very wealthy widow who has fallen in Love with
& perforce wedded him.

I am going down to Scotland for a few weeks
& shall then be here till the Summer. Any chance
of your being in London next Spring? How delighted
we shdshould be to shewshow you the Regents Park which I
think must have been in an unfinished
condition when you last played Lion in these
parts.

I don't think there is any news. Your Countryman
Mr Moore is in town & has begun printing his
huge Quarto Life of Lord Byron which I hope
will be plainer & truer than his Life of

of Mr Sheridan. He has great Materials - but
they are all his own & Murray's - for Mr Hobhouse
& Mr Kinnaird both say I think wisely & well
that Byron's poem will take care of themselves
& that no friend of his Memory wdwould wish to write
about his personal character & history in
detail so long as Lady B &c &c are alive.
They therefore refuse all aid to Mr Thomas.
Sir H. Davy is wintering at Bologna whence
he has lately sent a valuable paper to the
Royal Society on Electrical animals with the
melancholy announcement that he then
takes leave of Experimental Philosophy
finding his nerves wholly unfit for such
works. I hope he will write books like his
Salmonia for the ignorant Public.
div.closer:
Believe me always my dear Miss
Edgeworth your faithful & affectaffectionate Servant
J G Lockhart
